repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - The First, Second, Third, and
            Fourth Small and Medium Industries Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This impact evaluation report on the
            World Bank Support for Small and Medium Industries (SMIs) in
            the Philippines used a survey of more than 300 firms and 17
            participating financial institutions (PFIs) to analyze the
            impact of the Bank's strategy on SMIs. The results
            indicate first that support to SMIs resulted in more
            middle-income jobs, although jobs in larger firms were more
            productive. Second, Bank support for SMIs was part of a
            broader financial sector dialogue that was fruitful. The
            financial system became stronger and deeper and almost
            certainly helped the economy sustain the shocks felt by its
            neighbors. More directly, the credit risk of the commercial
            banking sector was reduced: Also, the repayment record of
            assisted SMIs was considerably better than that of large
            firms. Hence, SMI lending was less risky and helped improve
            the soundness of the banking sector. A final finding is that
            SMI lending was an inexpensive way to support new job
            creation. Lessons learned were four: 1) SMIs can be
            effective job creation programs. 2) SMI lending through
            financial intermediaries can support banking sector
            soundness. Directed credit programs that can improve banking
            sector soundness are possible. 3) SMIs could use more
            flexible financial products: they confront higher real
            borrowing costs because they have higher transaction costs.
            4) SMIs could participate in more market-driven technical assistance.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Small and Medium Industries
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Small and Medium Industries
            Development Project will be used by the Development Bank of
            the Philippines (DBP) and the Industrial Guarantee Loan Fund
            (IGLF) to finance fixed assets and permanent working capital
            for a wide range of small and medium industries sub-projects
            in manufacturing, agro-industries, transportation services,
            small engineering facilities, and small construction
            industries. It will be used by the National Economic and
            Development Authority (NEDA) to finance the establishment of
            24 industrial producer cooperatives and by the Indonesian
            government to establish 7 Regional Technical Assistance
            Centres (RTACs) to provide technical assistance to small industries.
